document_title: Acute kidney failure: Causes, signs, treatment and prevention
subsection_content:
Acute kidney failure (or acute kidney injury) is an acute decrease in glomerular filtration rate over a few hours to a few days, causing excess electrolytes and wastes to not be eliminated from the blood. The disease can occur in people with previously normal kidney function or in people with chronic kidney disease.
This condition causes toxins to accumulate in the body and is life-threatening, if the patient has some additional diseases such as cardiovascular, pulmonary... However, the patient has the ability to fully recover. if detected promptly and treated properly.
Currently, acute kidney failure is divided according to factors where the disease occurs such as: acute kidney failure acquired in the community, acquired in the hospital and acquired in the intensive care unit. (first)
